overview_metadata.overview_title: Been There, Done That, Got the T-Shirt
overview_metadata.overview_description: In this lesson, students calculate slope using a formula and directly from a table. They explain the meaning of positive, negative, undefined, and zero slopes. Students identify the y-intercept from situations, graphs, and tables and calculate the y-intercept using the slope formula and two points.

overview_item_data_items: I can determine the y-intercept of a linear equation from a context, table, or graph.
I can calculate and interpret the rate of change from a table of values or two coordinate pairs.
I can determine whether a table of values represents a linear proportional, linear non-proportional, or non-linear relationship.
I can interpret the meaning of the initial value in the context of a linear relationship.
You can characterize a line by its slope and y-intercept. You can identify the slope and the y-intercept in any of its representations.

The slope formula is <math><mi>m</mi><mo>=</mo><mfrac><mrow><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow><mrow><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>-</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></mrow></mfrac></math> where the first point is <math><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></math> and the second point is <math><mo>(</mo><msub><mi>x</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>y</mi><mn>2</mn></msub><mo>)</mo></math>.
The slope of an increasing line is positive, a decreasing line is negative, a horizontal line is 0, and a vertical line is undefined.

To determine whether a table of values represents a linear relationship, you can show that the slope is the same between every set of ordered pairs. Where a table contains consecutive x-values, you can calculate the first differences instead of slopes.
When the y-intercept is not apparent in a table or graph, you can use the slope formula and given points to calculate its exact value.

overview_item_data_group_items.overview_item_data_group_item_descriptio: Students consider representations of a linear relationship.
Students use a right triangle on a graph to verify the slope of a line.
Students calculate slope from a table.
Students identify the y-intercept from situations and graphs.
Students determine whether a table and a graph represent a linear relationship.
